description:
Aspergillus foveolatus is a species of filamentous fungus that belongs to the genus Aspergillus. It is a member of the Aspergillus section Fumigati, which includes several species known to be opportunistic pathogens.

Aspergillus foveolatus is characterized by its dark green to brown-colored colonies, with a velvety or powdery texture. The conidiophores (reproductive structures) are typically long and smooth, with a globose vesicle at the apex. The conidia (asexual spores) are spherical to subglobose in shape and have a distinctly foveolate (pitted) surface ornamentation.

This fungal species is commonly found in soil, decaying organic matter, and indoor environments. It has been isolated from various sources, including clinical samples, and has been associated with opportunistic infections in immunocompromised individuals, such as invasive aspergillosis.

Aspergillus foveolatus is closely related to other medically important Aspergillus species, such as Aspergillus fumigatus, and its identification and differentiation from similar species can be challenging, often requiring advanced molecular techniques.
